reviewText: A paean to individualism. "Never give an inch" is the motto of the Stamper family, independent loggers in Oregon. The union has called a strike, but the Stampers have a contract which they plan on honoring. Henry Fonda plays the patriarchal father; his three sons = Paul Newman, his spitting image personality-wise (Newman also directed); Richard Jaeckel, a happy-go-lucky fellow; and Michael Sarrazin, the black sheep prodigal son who comes home after 10 years' absence.The family fights off the animosity of the logging town, only to lose Jaeckel and Fonda to accidents when a tree falls on them. (Jaeckel drowns in what turns out to be the most moving scene in the movie.) Newman and Sarrazin get the logs through anyway. Lee Remnick is Newman's wife, miscast and too prissy - she leaves him after the accident.The Ken Kersey novel this was based on was huge (600+ pages) and showed great in-depth character development; the movie doesn't delve nearly as much and therefore disappoints: the characters are two-dimensional. The relationship between Sarrazin and Remick is glossed over and should be pivotal, especially with regard to her leaving Newman in the end. The movie is pretty good, but comes across as weak where it should be strongest.
summary: Bucking the tide in the Northwest forests
Title: N/A

reviewText: I remember first seeing this movie on TV in my teens, probably in the late '70's and was very moved by it. As curcumstances would have it, I moved to the Pacific Nortwet (no, that is not a spelling error) in the early '80's, and lived close a logging town (Shelton).  Got to know some of the people who made their living in the woods, and came to appreciate the humor and work ethic that went with hard living. My neighbor and his sons ran a large logging operation. Years later moved away, read the book and thought it a monumental work of American literature.So, with strong feelings of nostolgia about my time in the PNW, 30 years since I watched a most memorable movie, after living around these types of people, and a solid 20 years since I read Keasys spectacular book; the BIG QUESTION REMAINED "Has this movie aged well?".The BIG ANSWER:  Yes, it has.Yes there are a lot of details from the book that did not make it into the movie.  But I found that there were many subtleties that had.  I really enoyed revisiting this film.  Newman, Fonda, Remick, and the rest of the cast are all at the top of thier game.  Great stuff, this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Paul Newman's 'Sometimes a Great Notion' (Universal, 1971), based on Ken Kesey's book of the same name, is a surprisingly accomplished family drama championing-- even more surprisingly-- conservative political and social principles (Big Labor being cast as the antagonist as opposed to a corporation or the military-industrial complex sets SAGN apart from nearly every other 'message' movie of the '70s), although liberals need not necessarily feel excluded as the script and performances are stronger than any hard ideology.  While the Blu-ray doesn't offer extras other than a trailer, the quality of Shout Factory's hi-def print is pristine, highlighting some spectacular photography of SAGN's Oregon and Washington locations.  Film earns 4 stars, as does presentation.

reviewText: This epic, powerfully acted, and visually breathtaking movie beg for the Criterion DVD treatment.  What can they be waiting for?  The characters in this film, bigger than life, seem to be acted by the only actors who could possibly do justice to the roles.  The cinematography is lush and beautifully composed on location in the Pacific Northwest, and the dialogue keeps the film moving effortlessly, as though one were a member of the family of loggers portrayed in the film.  Sign me up to purchase the DVD as soon as it is released, hopefully by Criterion.
summary: Criterion, What Are You Waiting For?

reviewText: "Never give an inch".  The Stamper family logging business demonstrate this by continuing to work to fulfill a contract as their striking union brethren suffer.  Is it bad luck or divine retribution to punish their arrogance at play as the Stampers race against time to fill the order?  There are a lot of ambiguities in "Sometimes a Great Notion" which includes the ending and no easy answers.  The film isn't so much concerned with a smooth narrative and when you think about it life doesn't follow a script.  This is an examination of the individuals who comprise a family unit and there is a malignancy that runs through the Stampers.  Each character is carefully drawn out and imbued with shades of gray instead of being painted in black and white.  Paul Newman, Henry Fonda, and Lee Remick are fine but the best performances to my mind belong to Michael Sarrazin as the depressive half brother Leeland and Richard Jaeckel in an Oscar nominated turn as the lighthearted brother Joe Ben.  The second film directed by Newman, "Rachel, Rachel" being the first, shows him to be adept behind the camera.  I haven't read Ken Kesey's source novel so I don't know how faithful the film is to it but this is compelling cinema.

reviewText: Paul Newman gives one of his best performaces in this well acted and realistic film about modern day loggers in Oregon. He plays Hank Stamper, A true spirtied indidvualist who belives strongly in princple comes under  fire from the local townspeople when he and his famliy refuse to give up on  a logging contract thus putting the entire town in finacial ruin. And more  turmoil comes from withen the Stamper Family when Lee(Hank`s Half brother)  comes back home and tries to end a personal vendetta with Hank(He faults  Hank for his Mother`s suicide because Lee saw Hank and his Mother making  love)There`s also another crisis in the famliy Viv, Hank`s Love starved  wife played beautiful by the Late Lee Remick tries hard to get attention  from her husbend but she gets tired of being neglected and feels her life  would be better living somewhere else and leaves him.  The best scene in  this film is of course the drowing scene When Hank tries to save his cousin  Joe Ben who is pinned down by a massive log with his head just inches above  the rising water Hank tries despertly to save his cousin by mouth to mouth  as long as he could but the water swept him Joe and drowned, A heart  wrenching moment. But in the end the remaining Stampers Hank And Lee  managed to put aside their personal diffrences and fulfill their contract  and haul all the logs along the river. The ending was funny and sick at the  same time when Hank uses the disemboided arm of his late father`s and  extends the middle finger high above on the boat so everyone can see that  that the family is still going strong and never gives an inch, A great film  with a great cast. This film is certainly on my classic film list.
summary: A Notion:This Is One Great Film!

Sad to watch now because all yes,all major stars in this movie have pasted away...except for Mr.Sarrazin. The way Richard Jaeckel dies is very real. reviewText: Firstly, I cannot stress enough that one read the novel. It is one of the finest American novels ever written.Kesey's superb epic novel with its shifting points of view and verb tense is far too complex a work to adapt directly to the camera's limited third person POV. Kesey's rich and dense narrative prose, while exceptionaly cinematic in its description and action ironically proves unfilmable.That said, Paul Newman and his production team created a most admirable and solid, if very truncated adaptation of Kesey's excellent novel. It is near impossible to fit the novel's rumbling narrative into a mere hour and a half.Unlike the more famous film version of Cuckoo's Nest, Kesey admires this filming of his work. It is important viewing on that note alone.Sadly missing is the critical sub-plot involving a love triangle between Lee and Vivian. As a result, a great deal of Lee's motivation and narrative tension is lost. According to Kesey, the triangle was filmed but lopped off to save running time. Maybe it will come back in the DVD version.The dialouge, while rather shallow and weak in spurts (much of Kesey's rich vernacular is lost- save for the brilliant aphorisistic interjection "Boy, Howdy!"), is effectively and evocatively brought to life by a wonderful ensemble cast featuring some of America's finest. Who better than Henry Fonda to play Newman's father. Richard Jaekel richely earns his Oscar nomination as the dim-witted but enthusiastic born again lumberjack JoBen. The famous drowning scene is heartbreakingly tragic and darkly comic and this owes directly to both the expert acting of Newman and Jaekel and Newman's own expert direction.Newman spent a great deal of time in my native Oregon researching the part. He also invited Kesey to hang around on the set and the two of them partied a great deal together. Newman's homework shows vividly as much of Kesey's descriptions resound intact in the brilliant photography presented here. The sense of time and place is impressively captured in the framing of the omnipresent rusting metal, dripping ferns, rotting wood and mildewed carpets that one sees on the Oregon coast. This is a film that one can almost smell.Special note must be also made of Henry Mancini's twangy country score. It sounds exactly like something found in a juke box in some coastal dive circa 1970.Newman is one of the finest artists ever to come out of Hollywood. Not only as an actor, but also as a director. He instinctivly knows how to illicit naturalistic, comfortable and utter human performances from his casts and Sometimes A Great Notion is no exception. This is not a great film, by any stretch, but it is most definately a film worth seeing.

reviewText: Legend has it that Ken Kesey got his inspiration for One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest from working in a mental hospital. If so, wonder what inspired him to write about an Oregon logging family beset by union workers, discord, and disaster in Sometimes a Great Notion. Final scenes of Newman floating down the river with his handmade prop giving a not so nice salute pretty much sums up Kesey, Newman, Fonda, and all the other antiheroes that abounded in the 60s and 70s.
summary: papa fonda and son newman against the world
Title: N/A

reviewText: It took me weeks to read all 628 pages of this book, all the time looking forward to seeing the film. On one hand, the cast was wonderful - especially  Henry Fonda and Paul Newman, as father and son. The movie went a long way in capturing the feel of the fictional town of Wakonda, including the river and many of the secondary characters found within the book.However, it would be practically impossible for any group of filmmakers and actors to translate the magic found within the pages of this novel onto the silver screen. While I salute and commend the people behind this film, there was no reasonable way to include all the richness of the novel in a Hollywood film. Certain key elements of the book were left out of the movie (Lee and Viv's romance being an important section left on the cutting-room floor). All in all, a noble effort but flawed and lacking compared to the book.
summary: Great Cast of Characters (but read the book instead)

reviewText: This film has very good actors, a realistic plot, and vivid scenery.  If you would enjoy learning about the culture of loggers in the NW, which I did, this is an excellent film.  Newman, a macho character and man of principle who is not sympathetic, is living his life according to his code.  This involves a sadly abusive marriage with the lovely Lee Remick and the decision to break a strike.  Like the best indie films, it is a true gem, complete on its own terms no matter what the triumph or the tragedy.REcommended.
summary: very good early indie film about a quirky community
Title: N/A

reviewText: The film is based on Ken Kesey's complex novel of a contemporary family of lumberjacks who stubbornly maintain 19th-century frontier values, and whose motto is "Never Give a Inch."The Stamper's patriarch, Henry (Henry Fonda), his son Hank (Newman) and nephew Joe Ben (Richard Jaeckel) alienate the entire community by refusing to participate in a local strike, because they're anti-union and want to honor their contract to deliver lumber... They overcome hostility, sabotage and violence, but succumb to nature...Hank is another of Newman's tough, macho individualist, somewhat like "Hud." He brawls, hunts, drinks beer constantly, has no social conscience, and is coldly sarcastic, especially toward the strikers and his half-brother Lee (Michael Sarrazin), a hippie with pro-union and women's lib ideas... Hank shares his father's professional pride, rigid conservatism and purpose in life: 'To work and eat and sleep and screw and drink--that's all there is." The women play a marginal role, as is customary in male adventure films--they cook, clean and are passive sex objects...Despite the ideological schizophrenia, ill-defined relationships and implausible plot resolutions, the film is surprisingly stirring...Newman captures with zest the details of logging and the robust family life, as well as the kind of exhilarating camaraderie and professionalism that characterized the best thirties adventure films...This extroverted masculine adventure contrasts sharply with the two introverted, confined, feminine dramas he has directed, but, interestingly, the combination of toughness and sensitivity constitutes Newman's own screen image...The delicate balance between humor and horror, the suspenseful drawing out of time, the genuine feeling of brotherly love, the finely judged performances (Jaeckel was nominated for an Oscar), and Newman's expert use of long shots (emphasizing their utter desolation) and closeups (giving us a sense of claustrophobia) create the best scene he ever directed...

reviewText: UPDATE (3-22-2011):  It's unfortunate that Amazon continues to lump together the various reviews of a particular film that derive from disparate sources.  My below-listed review of "Sometimes A Great Notion", for example, was written on behalf of two non-U.S. dvd region (PAL) versions that came out quite a while ago, and have nothing to do with this new Universal (2011) Vault Series version.  I don't know why Europe was so far ahead of the U.S. in getting this wonderful film to dvd, but I suspect that this new "manufacturing on demand" (MOD) dvd will be quite satisfactory.  Better late, than never; at least now, you don't need to buy a region-free dvd player to watch Paul Newman et al bring this powerful story to life.UPDATE (12-21-2012):  I just watched the new bluray of this film, and it is so clearly better than any of the preceding dvds that I have deleted those comments.  You will, however, have to shut off the curious English subtitles.  Enjoy!

reviewText: Knowing nothing about this firm, apart from the very handy cast, I was surprised and pleased how good it was. The story is simple and not especially original - a family in the logging business defy a strike by the unionised labour in their district and keep working - but it is told with considerable intelligence and gusto.The entire cast are excellent; they are working with a strong script (an adaptation from a book, which I have not read); and Paul Newman proves himself a skilful director, in this first-up effort. The film's greatest impact point, however, is its setting, in Oregon, and the extensive and exciting sequences of tree felling, trimming, hauling and rafting. These are not fillers; they lie at the heart of the film and drive the narrative. Two scenes stand out, in particular - BEWARE PLOT SPOILER - when Hank (Newman's character) is trying to keep his brother (who is trapped under a log in the river) from drowning, by mouth to mouth resuscitation underwater; and Henry Fonda, the mortally injured family patriarch Henry Stamper, in hospital, defying death right to his last gasp.The central conflict is between the independent, accountable-to-no-one Stamper family and the lumbermen's union, but the more telling commentary on the Stamper philosophy is provided by Lee Remick's character, Hank's wife. On the back of a typically sensitive and wry Remick performance, she is the real counterpoint to the macho, 'life is work, shagging and drinking' worldview the family personify. It's not that she wishes to tear it down or even repudiate it; she simply finds it is not enough.The camerawork and editing are first class. The DVD looks and sounds great. There is enormous energy in the production, which builds to a powerful and convincing conclusion.
Title: N/A
